pullrequest.title: Moved Jose's pull request #797 to gazebo 2.1

content.raw:
Here's an idea. Since we are packaging bullet, we could make it a mandatory dependency on Gazebo. 

Pros: We'll test Bullet more often. It'll reduce cmake complexity. We'll probably make bullet mandatory in the near future anyway.

Cons: Another dependency that users have to install when compiling from source.
content.html:
Here's an idea. Since we are packaging bullet, we could make it a mandatory dependency on Gazebo.

Pros: We'll test Bullet more often. It'll reduce cmake complexity. We'll probably make bullet mandatory in the near future anyway.

Cons: Another dependency that users have to install when compiling from source.

pullrequest.title: Moved Jose's pull request #797 to gazebo 2.1

content.raw:
Seems like two aspects to me:

1. deb dependency (auto-installs with gazebo deb)

2. cmake fatal error dependency (source build fails without bullet 2.82)

The halfway step would be to just make it a deb dependency.
content.html:
Seems like two aspects to me:

  1. deb dependency (auto-installs with gazebo deb)

  2. cmake fatal error dependency (source build fails without bullet 2.82)

The halfway step would be to just make it a deb dependency.

pullrequest.title: Moved Jose's pull request #797 to gazebo 2.1

content.raw:
I think number 1 is in the works.

Number 2 is the question for this pull request. Do we make it required? I'm in favor of making bullet a requirement.
content.html:
I think number 1 is in the works.

Number 2 is the question for this pull request. Do we make it required? I'm in favor of making bullet a requirement.

pullrequest.title: Moved Jose's pull request #797 to gazebo 2.1

content.raw:
One of our main consumers out there is ROS, which is one of the reasons why we are not depending on bullet in the deb package and I'm not sure that would accept to deliever our own bullet packages.

Anyway, it's an interesting idea to think about. My ideal situation would be to be able to implement somewhat a plugin system for physics engines and have different packages: ```libgazebo-bulllet``` or ```libgazebo-simbody```. which bring functionality dynamically to gazebo. Not sure about how complex this would be.
content.html:
One of our main consumers out there is ROS, which is one of the reasons why we are not depending on bullet in the deb package and I'm not sure that would accept to deliever our own bullet packages.

Anyway, it's an interesting idea to think about. My ideal situation would be to be able to implement somewhat a plugin system for physics engines and have different packages: libgazebo-bulllet or libgazebo-simbody. which bring functionality dynamically to gazebo. Not sure about how complex this would be.

pullrequest.title: Moved Jose's pull request #797 to gazebo 2.1

content.raw:
I agree that a plugin system would be ideal. It would take a little work.

Can't we build gazebo debians that depend on bullet2.82? At the same time we can require source builds to have bullet2.82 installed.
content.html:
I agree that a plugin system would be ideal. It would take a little work.

Can't we build gazebo debians that depend on bullet2.82? At the same time we can require source builds to have bullet2.82 installed.

pullrequest.title: Moved Jose's pull request #797 to gazebo 2.1

content.raw:
We can build gazebo debians with bullet2.82, no technical problem for that. What I could see as a problem would be the no-go of a third party about distribute our own 2.82 version of debian bullet, althought it can be co-installed, is a bit tricky to include in the system a different version of libbullet than the one chosen by the linux distribution.

And yes, we could make bullet mandatory at the same time for from-source compilations. My personal opinion about this point is that keeping it optional brings users and other downstream packagers flexibility, which is usually a good thing.
content.html:
We can build gazebo debians with bullet2.82, no technical problem for that. What I could see as a problem would be the no-go of a third party about distribute our own 2.82 version of debian bullet, althought it can be co-installed, is a bit tricky to include in the system a different version of libbullet than the one chosen by the linux distribution.

And yes, we could make bullet mandatory at the same time for from-source compilations. My personal opinion about this point is that keeping it optional brings users and other downstream packagers flexibility, which is usually a good thing.
